parties.title: ABC Pvt Ltd v. Union of India

cases.tldr60: SC clarifies scope of Section 34: courts may set aside an award for patent illegality apparent on the face, but cannot re-appreciate evidence; remand only when essential findings are missing. This limits judicial interference in arbitration.

brief5min.facts: Parties disputed a services contract; arbitral tribunal awarded damages to ABC. The Union challenged on patent illegality and jurisdictional error.
brief5min.issues: (1) Whether alleged patent illegality justified interference under s.34. (2) Whether tribunal exceeded jurisdiction in awarding heads of damages.
brief5min.holding: Limited interference permitted: parts of the award ignoring mandatory clauses were set aside; factual re‑appreciation disallowed.
brief5min.reasoning: The Court distinguished mere erroneous application from 'patent illegality'. Contractual bar on consequential damages was ignored by tribunal, warranting partial set‑aside.
brief5min.disposition: Award partially set aside; matter not remanded; costs quantified; directions issued for payment of undisputed sums.

keyQuotes.quote: Section 34 is not an appellate provision; re‑appreciation is impermissible.
Patent illegality must be apparent on the face of the award.

cases.tldr60: DHC narrows interim injunction against critic's clips, holding review excerpts may be fair dealing if transformative and limited; platform takedown restored only for full‑length uploads. Balances copyright with free speech.

brief5min.facts: PQR sought a blanket injunction over video reviews containing short clips. Trial court granted broad takedown.
brief5min.issues: Whether short, transformative excerpts for critique qualify as fair dealing under s.52.
brief5min.holding: Yes, where excerpts are necessary, brief, and linked to commentary; blanket bans are disproportionate.
brief5min.reasoning: Critique serves public interest; proportionality guides interim relief; market substitution not shown for short clips.
brief5min.disposition: Injunction modified; selective takedown for infringing full uploads maintained.

keyQuotes.quote: Transformative purpose tempers exclusivity at the interim stage.

cases.tldr60: Court clarifies legitimate interests test: controllers must show a specific, present interest and a reasoned necessity; generic 'fraud prevention' claims are insufficient. Data protection requires concrete justification.

brief5min.facts: ICO upheld a penalty for processing without a valid basis. X Ltd relied on legitimate interests for broad analytics.
brief5min.issues: Whether X Ltd identified a concrete legitimate interest and whether processing was necessary and balanced fairly.
brief5min.holding: Interest too generic; some narrow analytics were justified; penalty recalculated.
brief5min.reasoning: A lawful basis needs a specific objective and evidence of necessity; balancing favored data subjects for profiling segments.
brief5min.disposition: Appeal allowed in part; matter remitted to ICO for reassessment.

keyQuotes.quote: Necessity is not convenience; it is a real need for the chosen means.
